text.1: It has been explained in the initial commentary of Surah al-Baqarah that the beginnings of Surahs that commence with letters of the alphabet such as Alif Lam Mim, Kaf Ha Ya 'Ain Shad and so on, are included in the "Mutasyabihat" verses, the true meaning of which is only known by Allah. The purpose is to serve as a reminder and to increase attention regarding the Qur'an, which contains many profound wisdoms and secrets.
text.2: What is being read here is an explanation of your Lord's mercy bestowed upon one of His servants who was already old, namely the Prophet Zakaria (peace be upon him), when he prayed to be granted a righteous child. Prophet Zakaria was from the descendants of the Children of Israel (Bani Israil) who became a prophet after the Prophet Yunus to lead his people.
text.3:
That is, when he prayed in a soft and secluded voice in his mihrab, so that he would be given offspring who would continue the task of prophethood. His prayer was intentionally uttered in a soft voice and in a state of solitude, so that it would feel more sincere and be answered. Then the Qur'an mentions what his prayer sounded like. Indeed, praying is commanded by Allah to all of us with tawadhu, which is humility and with a soft voice, not screaming, as mentioned in Allah's word:

"Call upon your Lord in humility and privately; indeed, He does not like transgressors." (al-A'raf/7: 55)
text.4:
In his prayer, Prophet Zakaria stated, among other things, "O my Lord, indeed I beseech the acceptance of this prayer because of several reasons that I believe will open Your grace and favor. First, I have reached a very old age, almost ninety years old, where I already feel my bones are weak, and the weakness of the skeletal frame also results in a comprehensive weakness throughout my body, and someone as old as I am is very worthy of being pitied and shown compassion. Second, my head is full of gray hair, so anyone who looks at me will surely feel compassion and be moved to fulfill my request. Third, I have never been disappointed in praying to You, O Lord, since I was young, let alone now when my weakness has become entirely apparent."

Prophet Zakaria himself knew that if his prayer was answered, it would bring many improvements in the fields of religion and society. Therefore, he continued his prayer as mentioned in the following verse.
text.5:
And indeed, I am worried about those who will control and lead my people, because there is no one trustworthy among them, therefore I ask to be granted a child. Even though my wife is barren and I myself am very old, this does not cause me to despair, because I believe in the wisdom and power of Allah the Most Great. Despair is indeed forbidden by Allah, as in some of His words, namely:

"...and do not despair of the mercy of Allah. Indeed, no one despairs of the mercy of Allah except the disbelieving people." (Yusuf/12: 87)

And the word of Allah:

"He (Abraham) said, "And who despairs of the mercy of his Lord except for those astray?" (al-Hijr/15: 56)
text.6:
This verse mentions the content of Prophet Zakariya's prayer, "O my Lord, grant me from Yourself a good offspring who will inherit me and inherit from the family of Jacob. And make him one who is worthy, obedient, and pleasing to You, because he possesses noble and virtuous character, and can be made an example by all his followers."

Indeed, praying for righteous offspring who will later become leaders for the righteous is commanded by Allah, as in His saying:

"And those who say, "Our Lord, grant us from our wives and our offspring comfort to [our] eyes and make us an example for the righteous." (al-Furqan/25:74)
text.7: In this verse, Allah informs us about the acceptance of Zechariah (Zakaria) a.s.'s prayer and the giving of his son's name directly from Allah Himself. Allah says to Zechariah, that indeed Allah gives him good tidings, that his request to be granted a son will be fulfilled, and it has also been prepared that his child, if born, will be named Yahya, and that name has never been given to anyone before him.
text.8: After being informed that he would have a son, Prophet Zakaria (peace be upon him) asked Allah. This question arose not from doubt about Allah's power, but to gain clarification about the manner in which it would happen, because he felt he was no longer capable of having a son, and his wife was barren. Would he be made like a young man again with sufficient physical strength, or would his wife be restored to a young woman who could give birth to a child, or would he have to marry another woman who was not barren? Because Zakaria was very happy with the news that he would have a child, and he was filled with wonder about the ways in which it would be carried out, he could not restrain himself from asking his Lord about it. So, he was answered with Allah's word in the following verse:
text.9:
The verse explains that Zechariah will be blessed with a son, even though he is very old and his wife is barren. That is easy for God. If Allah is able to create Adam from nothing at all and then bring him into existence, then creating a child from what already exists, namely Zechariah and his wife, is easier for Allah. Several of Allah's words below show that there is no difficulty whatsoever for Allah to create whatever He wills, including:

Do you not know that Allah knows what is in the heaven and the earth? Indeed, that is in a Record (al-Lauh al-Mahfuz). Indeed, that, for Allah, is easy. (al-Hajj/22:70)

And the word of Allah:

Have they not considered how Allah begins creation and then repeats it? Indeed, that, for Allah, is easy. (al-'Ankabut/29:19)
text.10:
Then, Prophet Zakaria pleaded again to Allah to be given signs that his son would soon be born, so that his heart would be more at peace and his gratitude would increase. He said, "My Lord, give me a sign that can increase the peace of my heart about the fulfillment of Your promise." Something like this also happened to Prophet Ibrahim a.s. when he was asked, "Do you not yet believe that Allah is able to bring the dead to life?" He answered, "Indeed, I believe, but I ask so that my heart may be more at peace." As mentioned in Allah's word:

And (remember) when Abraham said, "My Lord, show me how You give life to the dead." Allah said, "Have you not believed?" He (Abraham) said, "Yes, but to be reassured in my heart." He (Allah) said, "Then take four birds and train them to yourself. Then [after slaughtering them] put on each hill a portion of them; then call them - they will come [flying] to you in haste. And know that Allah is Exalted in Might, Wise." (al-Baqarah/2: 260)
text.11: Prophet Zakaria (peace be upon him) came out of the mihrab towards his people, who had been waiting for a long time because of their habit of praying in congregation with him in his place of worship in the morning and evening. They asked, "What caused him to be late in opening the door of his mihrab?" Then he gestured to them, to glorify Allah, sanctifying Him from polytheism, from the accusation of having a child, and from every attribute that is not befitting for Allah. They were commanded to glorify Him abundantly in the morning and evening.
text.12: Allah commanded Yahya to take the Torah, which was the greatest blessing from Allah to the Children of Israel, with full attention and sincerity, and to practice its contents with pure sincerity. Then Allah revealed the highly commendable qualities of the Prophet Yahya, which should be emulated by all his followers. Among them, Allah had given him wisdom and a very deep understanding of religion and enthusiasm to practice all good deeds, even when Yahya was still very young. It is narrated that he was once surrounded by children his age and invited to play together, then he replied, "We were created by God not to play. Come join me in prayer."
text.13:
Allah made Prophet Yahya a person who possessed compassion for his fellow human beings, especially the poor and needy, just as Allah made Prophet Muhammad saw possess the same feelings, as stated in Allah's word:

"So by mercy from Allah, [O Muhammad], you were lenient with them." (Ali 'Imran/3: 159)

And Allah's word:

"There has certainly come to you a Messenger from among yourselves. Grievous to him is what you suffer; [he is] concerned over you and to the believers is kind and merciful." (at-Taubah/9: 128)

The character of Prophet Yahya was also pure from shirk and he always distanced himself from every action that caused Allah's displeasure. He was always pious, carrying out Allah's commands and avoiding His prohibitions.
text.14:
This verse explains the characteristic of Prophet Yahya who was always devoted to his parents, because devotion to them is made a virtuous deed after worshiping Allah, in accordance with His word:

And your Lord has decreed that you worship none but Him, and that you be dutiful to your parents. (al-Isra/17: 23)

Among the other characteristics of Prophet Yahya is that he was not arrogant towards other people, always humble, like the characteristic commanded to Prophet Muhammad saw in Allah's word:

And lower your wing [in kindness] to those who follow you of the believers. (asy-Syu'ara/26: 215)

And Allah's word:

And if you had been rude [in speech] and harsh in heart, they would have disbanded from about you. (Ali 'Imran/3: 159)

Because the characteristic of arrogance is very bad, so that it caused Iblis to be cursed because he was arrogant, refusing to prostrate in respect to Prophet Adam as, upon Allah's command. The last characteristic among the praiseworthy characteristics of Prophet Yahya is that he never opposed Allah's commands.
text.15: Allah explains the reward for the virtue of Prophet Yahya because of his obedience and piety, [and] safety, peace be upon him on the day he was born into the world, and on the day he died leaving this fleeting world, and on the day he is resurrected to life again on the Day of Judgment. These three events are mentioned because every human being in these three periods is in great need of God's mercy and grace.
text.16:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to narrate the story of Maryam as explained in the Qur'an, when Maryam, the mother of Prophet Isa, distanced herself from her family to a place located east of Baitul Makdis (Jerusalem) in order to find tranquility in worshiping Allah. Maryam wanted to escape from the routine of daily life.

Regarding this verse, Ibn Abbas said, "Among all people, I am the most knowledgeable about why the Christians made their qibla towards the East; that is, in accordance with Allah's word that Maryam calmed herself and distanced herself from her family to a place in the East, then they made the birthplace of Prophet Isa a.s. (peace be upon him) their qibla."
text.17: So Maryam made a screen (wall) that protected her from the sight of her family and other people. Then Allah sent the angel Gabriel to her in the form of a handsome and comely man to inform Maryam that she would give birth to a son without a father. As for the wisdom of Gabriel's coming in human form, it was so as not to cause fear in Maryam.
text.18: When Maryam saw a man in her secluded place, she sought refuge with Allah Ta'ala from any evil that might arise, saying, "Indeed, I seek refuge in the Most Merciful from you; do not disturb me if you fear Him, because everyone who fears Him always avoids acts of disobedience."
text.19: To reassure Maryam and dispel her suspicion, the Angel Gabriel said, "Indeed, I am only a messenger from your Lord, [sent] to give you [glad] tidings of a pure son." Angel Gabriel mentioned that he himself would deliver the news about the son, because he was commanded by Allah Ta'ala to breathe the spirit into Maryam's body.
text.20: Mary was very surprised to hear the news and with a tone of astonishment she said, "How can I have a son when no man has ever touched me; and I am not unchaste."
text.21: Gabriel answered Maryam's question by saying that Maryam would have a son even though she was not married or had any relations with a man; because that was the will of Allah the Almighty and that was easy for Him. Allah made a son from Maryam so that it would be a sign for mankind of His power. The giving of a son to Maryam was a mercy from Allah because later that son would become a Prophet who calls to the path of happiness in this world and the hereafter. And that is Allah's decree which cannot be changed."
text.22: After Gabriel explained the purpose of his arrival, Maryam (Mary) replied, "I submit myself to the decree of Allah." Then Gabriel breathed the spirit of Prophet Isa (Jesus) into Maryam, causing her to conceive; then she withdrew with her pregnancy to a place far from the crowds to avoid accusations and mockery from the Children of Israel (Bani Israil).
text.23: When Maryam felt the pain of childbirth approaching, she was forced to lean against the trunk of a date palm tree to ease the delivery; in deep sorrow she said, "Oh, would that I had died before this, and was a thing forgotten, out of sight!" She wished she had died before giving birth because she felt the weight of suffering from giving birth to a child without a father, which would result in accusations and mockery from her people who did not know the true story; or she wished to be something insignificant in the eyes of people, and forgotten, rather than suffer the extraordinary feeling of pressure and shame.
text.24: Then Jibril came and called out from a lower place, "Do not grieve, for indeed your Lord has provided a stream beneath you." This is a mercy for Maryam because the place was initially dry with no flowing water, but then there was a stream of clean water.
text.25: Gabriel then instructed Maryam to shake the date palm tree, and it would then drop ripe dates for her. And this was another mercy for Maryam, because initially the date palm tree had been dry, but by the will of Allah, it became green and fertile again and bore fruit as sustenance for Maryam.
text.26: Then Gabriel instructed Maryam to eat, drink, and be happy because she had received that sustenance and to dispel the sadness in her heart because Allah is powerful enough to clear her of all inappropriate accusations, so that Maryam would still be considered a pure woman who had never been tainted. If you see a person asking about her situation and the situation of her child, then gesture to him, "Indeed, I have vowed to myself to fast solely for the sake of the Most Gracious Lord, and I will not speak directly to any human being today, because my words might be rejected and not believed."
text.27: After Maryam was commanded to fast on the day she gave birth to her son and not to speak to anyone, and after there was assurance from Allah that her honor would remain preserved; then Maryam surrendered her entire fate to the decree of Allah. Maryam carried her child and brought him to her people, which caused her people to reproach her actions, saying, "O Maryam, indeed you have done a terrible thing."
text.28:
Then they added insults, mockery, and accusations to Maryam, saying, "O sister of Harun, your father was not a wicked man, nor was your mother an unchaste woman. How did you get this child?" Maryam was called "Sister of Harun" because it had become a custom of the Children of Israel (Bani Israil) to mention the names of the prophets and righteous people who came before.

It is narrated by al-Mugirah bin Syu'bah, who was sent by the Messenger of Allah (saw) to Najran in the land of Yemen where there were Christians, and they asked him, "Why do you read in the Qur'an, 'O sister of Harun,' when Harun and Musa lived long before the birth of Isa, the son of Maryam?" al-Mugirah did not have time to give an answer, and when he returned to Medina and appeared before the Messenger of Allah, he presented the question. The Messenger of Allah (saw) answered:

"Why didn't you tell them that it was their (Bani Israil's) custom to mention the names of the prophets and righteous people before them?" (Riwayat Ahmad)
text.29: Mary pointed to her son so that he would speak and explain her situation, because Mary had vowed not to speak to anyone and was certain that her son understood the signal. The Jews asked in astonishment, "How can we speak to a baby still in the cradle?" They suspected that Mary was mocking them.
text.30: Isa a.s., still in his mother's arms, then said, "Indeed, I am a servant of Allah. He will give me the scripture, the Gospel, and He will make me a prophet." This statement contains an explanation that his mother was a pious woman, because a prophet must be from the descendants of righteous and pure people.
text.31: Furthermore, the young Isa said, Allah will make me a blessed one wherever I may be, because I benefit people and guide them to the path of happiness; Allah has commanded me to establish prayer (salat) because in establishing prayer there is an act of purifying oneself from various kinds of outward and inward sins, Allah has also commanded me to pay zakat as long as I live in the world. Zakat aims to purify wealth, the soul, and provide assistance to the poor and needy.
text.32: The infant Jesus further explained that Allah had commanded him to be devoted to his mother, to be submissive and always do good to her. This statement also indicates the purity of Maryam, because if it were not so, the Prophet Jesus would not have been commanded to be devoted to his mother. Jesus further stated, "Allah has not made me arrogant because I always obediently worship Allah, nor has He made me wretched because I always do good to my mother."
text.33:
Furthermore, Isa prayed that peace and safety be bestowed upon him on three occasions: the day he was born, the day he died, and the day he is resurrected to life on the Day of Judgment. Thus, no one can harm him during these three events, which are the most difficult and critical events for every servant of Allah living in the world.

The Jews and Christians deny that Isa (peace be upon him) ever spoke when he was a baby and still in his cradle. They argue that if this had truly happened, the news would have spread widely among the general public, because the event would have been very strange and very attention-grabbing. They have investigated everywhere and have not found any information about it in their books.

For Muslims, this event remains a belief because it is mentioned in the Qur'an, which is certainly true. Because if Isa (peace be upon him) had not spoken as a child and cleared his mother of all dirty accusations, the Jews would have carried out the punishment of stoning against Maryam. It is very likely that only a few people witnessed the baby's speech, a limited number, so it did not spread widely among them.
text.34: In this verse, Allah affirms that Jesus is a servant of Allah who will become a prophet and to whom the Book will be revealed, possessing noble characteristics and morals, not as his people accused him, not a child of adultery, and not the son of Allah as his people later uttered and believed. What he said while he was still a baby in the cradle is the true statement and cannot be doubted, even though his people still doubted those statements and accused him of being a sorcerer. He is not a sorcerer as the Jews said, not the son of Allah as the Christians claimed, and not God as another group said. He is a servant of Allah who will be raised to be a prophet and messenger.
text.35:
In this verse, Allah reaffirms that Jesus is not the son of God. It is unreasonable and impossible for Allah to have a son because Allah does not need offspring like humans who, in their old age, greatly need help and care, and need someone to continue and maintain the results of their efforts or to glorify their name after they die. Allah does not need all of that because He is All-Powerful, always self-sufficient, not needing the help of others, as stated in His word:

Allah - there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of [all] existence. (Ali 'Imran/3: 2)

Exalted is Allah above all deficiencies and from all accusations uttered by the disbelievers. When He intends to create something, it is enough for Him to say "Kun" (Be!), and it comes into being. It is not difficult for Him to create a son without a father or to create humans without a mother and father, like creating Adam, and Allah says:

Indeed, the example of Jesus to Allah is like that of Adam. He created him from dust; then He said to him, "Be," and he was. (Ali 'Imran/3: 59)

Allah, the Most Perfect and so great in His power, could not possibly need a son because that would indicate weakness and deficient attributes.
text.36:
In this verse, Allah further explains the words of Jesus when he was still a baby in the cradle, in addition to his words in verses 30-33 of this Surah, namely, "Indeed, Allah is my Lord and your Lord, so worship Him." Jesus affirmed to his people that he was only a servant of Allah like them, even though he was born in an extraordinary way without a father. This does not indicate that he is the son of Allah, or that he is a God worthy of worship. He is only an ordinary human being created by Allah. Therefore, he invited his people to worship Allah who created him and created all creatures. The only One worthy of their worship is Allah, the Creator of all things.

Furthermore, Jesus explained to them that humans should worship Allah, not worship Satan and idols. This is the straight path that will lead them to happiness in this world and the Hereafter. This is also the path shown by the prophets before him. Whoever takes that path will be happy, and whoever takes a path other than that will be misguided and wretched.
text.37:
Then, in this verse, Allah explains that the people of Prophet Isa did not heed the guidance given to them. They had fallen into a valley of error and great disagreement. They were divided into several groups: The "Jacobites," who followed the teachings of a priest named Jacob, who said that Isa was a god who was sent down to earth but then ascended back to heaven. The "Nestorians," who followed the teachings of a priest named Nestur, who said that Isa was the son of God who was sent down to earth and then raised back to heaven by Him. This group said that Isa was one of the three persons: the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. Another group said that Isa was one of the three gods: Allah, Isa His son, and Maryam the mother of Isa. Besides these misguided groups, there was also a righteous group who believed in accordance with the teachings and guidance of Isa, believing that Isa was a servant of Allah and His Messenger; this group was called "Malakania."

Regarding these misguided groups, Allah threatens them that they will witness for themselves how terrible the Day of Judgment will be and how painful the punishment prepared for them will be. All their limbs will bear witness to their disbelief and denial. Allah postpones the punishment for them until the Day of Judgment and does not hasten their punishment solely because of His mercy and compassion, as mentioned in the words of the Prophet saw:

Indeed, Allah postpones the punishment for the oppressor, but when He seizes him, he will not be able to escape that punishment. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Musa)

Regarding the attitude of the people of Prophet Isa, Prophet Muhammad saw said:

No one is more patient than Allah in hearing hurtful words. They say that Allah has a son, while Allah continues to provide them with sustenance and health. (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abdullah bin Qais)
text.38:
On the Day of Judgment, the disbelievers, contemplating their unfortunate fate, will have their ears become very sensitive and their sight very sharp, paying immediate attention to everything that happens. Then Allah will say, "How perceptive their hearing and how sharp their sight will be when they face Us. Yet, in the world, they were as if deaf, unable to hear the guidance brought by the Prophet, and as if blind, unable to see the truth and the miracles given to the messengers. They did not see or feel the power of Allah that is clearly visible in the universe."

If they had used their hearing and sight in the world as they will in the Hereafter, they would not have remained in disbelief; they would have believed in Allah and His Messenger. But there is no use for sensitive ears and sharp eyes at that time, because their fate has been determined and they will surely enter Hell. At that time, they will feel deep regret and wish they could be returned to the world to correct their mistakes and disobedience, but what is done is done. That empty wish will not be granted because they will be shackled, chained, and thrown into Hell, as mentioned in Allah's words:

(Allah will say), "Seize him and shackle him, then cast him into the blazing Fire. Then fasten him with a chain seventy cubits long. Indeed, he did not believe in Allah, the Most Great." (al-Haqqah/69: 30-33)

Such will be their fate in the Hereafter because they are people who have truly strayed from the straight path.
text.39:
In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to warn mankind, especially the polytheists of Mecca, about the Day of Judgment. They will die in a state of disbelief, and the disbelievers will regret not believing and always striving to uphold falsehood during their lives in the world.

The believers will be taken to Paradise, and the disbelievers will be driven to Hell. Both groups will be informed that they will never leave the place prepared for them, and they will never experience death. It is narrated in a hadith from Abu Sa'id, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said, "At that time, 'death' will be brought in the form of a fine-looking ram. Then someone will call out, 'O inhabitants of Paradise!' They will be stunned and pay attention. Then the caller will ask, 'Do you know what this is?' They will answer, 'Yes, that is 'Death.'' They will all see it. Then another caller will call out, 'O inhabitants of Hell! Do you know what this is?' They will answer, 'Yes! That is 'Death.'' They will also see it. Then 'death' in the form of a ram will be slaughtered between Paradise and Hell, and the caller will say, 'O inhabitants of Paradise, you will abide forever in Paradise and you will never experience death again. O inhabitants of Hell, you will abide forever in Hell and you will never experience death again.'" Then the Messenger of Allah recited this verse. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

At that time, the disbelievers will realize their negligence and regret why they denied the Day of Resurrection in the past, why they did not want to think about the invitation and guidance to the right path, but that regret will be of no use anymore.
text.40: In this verse, Allah comforts the Prophet Muhammad, asking him not to grieve because the polytheists do not want to believe and always deny him. Because they will eventually return to Allah and their disbelief will be recompensed with a fitting reward, for We are the All-Powerful. We are the ones who will inherit the earth and all that is in it on the Day of Resurrection.
text.41:
In these verses, Allah commands the Messenger to explain to the polytheists of Mecca the story of Prophet Ibrahim, whom they considered the father of the Arab nation. They considered themselves his descendants and claimed to be followers of his religion. However, Prophet Ibrahim was a believer, a beloved of Allah, and a Prophet who worshipped the One God, not a polytheist who worshipped idols. Allah commanded Muhammad to tell them when Prophet Ibrahim forbade his people from worshipping idols and said to his father as follows, "Why do you worship idols that cannot hear the praise of their worshippers when they are worshipped, cannot see how devoted you are to worshipping them, cannot help those who worship them and provide even the slightest benefit, and cannot ward off danger when the worshipper asks for help?"

With gentle and reasonable words, Prophet Ibrahim called his father to monotheism and to abandon the worship of idols, inanimate objects that are powerless. Even humans, who can hear and see and can provide help, are not worthy of worship, let alone inanimate objects that we make ourselves. If we want to damage or destroy them, they are powerless to defend themselves. Such things, which cannot possibly provide benefit or help to humans, are not worthy of being worshipped by humans. This is in accordance with the parable explained by Allah in His word:

"O people, an example is presented, so listen to it. Indeed, those you invoke besides Allah will never create [as much as] a fly, even if they gathered together for that purpose. And if the fly should steal away from them a [tiny] thing, they could not recover it from him. Weak are the pursuer and pursued." (al-hajj/22: 73)

text.43: Furthermore, Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) said to his father that he had been given knowledge by Allah that his father did not yet know. With that knowledge, Ibrahim could lead people to the straight path and free them from actions that degraded their status, while leading them to happiness in this world and the hereafter. Even though he was his son and much younger, Allah had bestowed His mercy upon Ibrahim by granting him that knowledge. Ibrahim greatly desired that his father follow him, so that he could bring his father to the straight path.
text.44: O my father, do not follow the teachings of Satan that lead you to worship idols, because Satan always deceives humans so that they stray from the right path. Indeed, Satan is a creature who is disobedient to his Lord, a creature who is very arrogant and conceited, therefore Allah curses him and distances him from His mercy. Because Satan has been angered by Allah, he is determined to always try to mislead humans. Do not let my father be among those who are deceived by Satan and fall into his trap. I fear that if my father continues to follow his teachings, my father will be afflicted with the wrath of Allah, like the wrath that has befallen Satan, and surely my father will be among his group.
text.45: O my father, do not follow the teachings of Satan that lead you to worship idols, because Satan always deceives humans so that they stray from the right path. Indeed, Satan is a creature who is disobedient to his Lord, a creature who is very arrogant and conceited, therefore Allah curses him and distances him from His mercy. Because Satan has been angered by Allah, he is determined to always try to mislead humans. Do not be among those who are deceived by Satan and fall into his trap. I fear that if you continue to follow his teachings, you will be afflicted with the wrath of Allah like the wrath that has befallen Satan, and surely you will be among his group.
text.46: The father of Prophet Ibrahim rejected his son's invitation, which was delivered in a gentle tone, with harsh and sharp words that revealed extreme denial and anger. His father said, "Do you despise the idols that I worship, that I glorify and that I exalt, O Ibrahim? Are you not aware of the error of your understanding? Are not the idols that I worship the objects of worship of all your people? Are not the gods that I glorify the objects of worship of your ancestors since ancient times? Have you gone mad or been possessed by a demon with your claim that you have received knowledge from the true God? If you do not stop your call, I will stone you to death, or leave my side, even this land, and do not return." Hearing this very harsh rebuttal and response, Ibrahim's heart was crushed because he loved and respected his father very much and greatly desired that he be freed from the error of worshiping idols and receive guidance to the right path, and be willing to believe in Allah, the One and Almighty. He wanted his father to receive grace and mercy from his Lord through faith. But what could he do and say, when his father was already enraged and expelled him from his home and homeland, even not wanting him to return, as if he were no longer his son.
text.47:
There was no response from Ibrahim to his father's harsh rebukes except to say, "Peace be upon you." I pray that father will always be in good health and well-being. I will not respond to those harsh words with harshness as you are my father whom I love. I will not do anything that harms or endangers father, let me leave this land, leaving father, leaving home and hometown. I ask God to forgive father and always be under His mercy, to be guided to the straight path that leads to goodness and happiness. Indeed, Prophet Ibrahim a.s. prayed for him as mentioned in Allah's word:

"And forgive my father, indeed, he has been of those astray." (Asy-Syu'ara/26: 86)

Prophet Ibrahim a.s. was certain that God would grant his prayer because usually in the past his prayers were always granted. Prophet Ibrahim prayed for his father because he had promised him that he would believe, as mentioned in Allah's word:

And the request of forgiveness of Ibrahim for his father was only because of a promise he had made to him. But when it became clear to Ibrahim that his father was an enemy to Allah, he disassociated himself from him. Indeed, Ibrahim was one who was soft-hearted and forbearing. (at-Taubah/9: 114)
text.48:
Furthermore, Ibrahim said to his father, "I will go away from you, away from your people, away from the idols you worship. I will leave from here so that I am free to worship my Lord who will help me and release me from the dangers that befall me, because all my guidance and advice you reject outright, even threatening me with terrible threats. I will worship and pray only to my Lord and I will never worship anything besides Him."

According to a narration, Ibrahim migrated to the land of Syria and there he married Siti Sarah. He hoped that by praying and worshipping God, he would not become a person who is disappointed like his father who always worshipped and prayed to those idols, but it turned out that the idols could not do anything, let alone fulfill what was asked of them.
text.49:
After Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) left his land of Ur Kildan (Iraq) and settled in the land of Sham, God blessed him with a prosperous and happy life. Allah blessed him with children and grandchildren, some of whom Allah elevated to be prophets among the Children of Israel (Bani Israil). Allah blessed him with Isaac, and Isaac had a son named Jacob who succeeded him as a Prophet. As for his first son, Ismail, whom he left in the vicinity of the Ka'bah, he was also appointed as a Prophet who elevated and enlivened the symbols of religion there.

Such is the reward of God to Prophet Ibrahim who was willing to leave his father, his people, and his homeland for the sake of the safety of his faith and to spread the religion of monotheism that Allah commanded him. Allah did not neglect or waste his sacrifice, but rather replaced the sadness of leaving his family and homeland with the happiness of a new family and homeland, and with people who accepted his teachings and guidance, and gave him good descendants, some of whom became upholders of the religion of Allah, and many of whom became prophets.
text.50:
In this verse, Allah explains that almost all of Prophet Ibrahim's children and grandchildren were appointed by Him as prophets and bestowed upon them His mercy and grace, blessing their lives with pleasure and happiness both in this world and in the hereafter. They all left behind a good and fragrant name, and elevated the name of Prophet Ibrahim, so that his glory and high status are acknowledged by all parties, whether from among the Jews, Christians, or even the polytheists themselves. This is a clear fact of the fulfillment of Prophet Ibrahim's prayer as mentioned in the verse:

"And grant me a reputation of honor among later generations." (ash-Shu'ara'/26: 84)

It is fitting that Allah raised his status and named him "Khalilullah" (His beloved) as mentioned in the verse:

"And Allah took Abraham as an intimate friend." (an-Nisa'/4: 125)

And made the imprint of his feet when building the Ka'bah a blessed place, and it is recommended to pray there as mentioned in the verse:

"And [mention, O Muhammad], when We made the House a place of return for the people and [a place of] security. And take, [O believers], from the standing place of Abraham a place for prayer." (al-Baqarah/2: 125)
text.51:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to explain to the polytheists the story of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) and the virtues of his characteristics, so that the Prophet himself and his people may know how Allah honored and glorified him. Among the privileges of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) is that he was chosen by Allah and made sincere by Him solely to convey the da'wah of the religion of monotheism, as was his da'wah to Pharaoh and his people, as mentioned in this verse:

"(Allah) said, "O Moses, I have chosen you above the people with My messages and My words. So take what I have given you and be among the grateful." (al-A'raf/7: 144)

Allah elevated him as a messenger in addition to being a prophet. The difference between a messenger (rasul) and a prophet (nabi) is that a messenger has a message that must be conveyed to mankind and a book is revealed to him containing creed, laws, and so on, while a prophet is someone who receives revelation from Allah about the true religion and informs people about it, but does not have a message that must be conveyed to mankind and no book is revealed to him. Among the Children of Israel, there were many prophets whose task was only to preserve and convey the Sharia brought by Prophet Musa, which is mentioned in the Torah, such as Joshua, Elijah, and others.
text.52:
In this verse, it is explained how Allah called Musa (peace be upon him) and spoke directly to him on the right side of Mount Tur, a mountain located in the Sinai Peninsula. At that time, Musa was heading to Egypt from Madyan to deliver his message to Pharaoh. It was on Mount Tursina that Musa was informed by Allah that he had been appointed as a messenger and promised him that he would be victorious in facing the tyrannical Pharaoh who claimed himself to be God. God also promised him that He would bestow mercy upon the family of Bani Israil by revealing the Torah.

Allah also explains that He brought Musa near to Him at the time of speaking, meaning that He honored him and chose him as His Messenger, as if Musa at that time was close to God as a king is close when speaking with his minister. We cannot know how God spoke directly to Musa. Did Musa actually hear a voice, or did Musa only feel that he was in a high spiritual realm as if hearing divine revelation? We cannot know how the actual event occurred; we must surrender all of that to Allah, the Almighty. Our obligation as believers is only to believe it, because it is narrated in the Al-Qur'an.
text.53:
Among Allah's mercies upon Moses was that Allah granted his request that Aaron, his brother from the same mother, also be appointed as a prophet to assist him in conveying the message of his Lord, as mentioned in the verse:

"And appoint for me a helper from my family, (that is) Aaron, my brother. Strengthen my back by him, and let him share in my task." (Taha/20: 29-30-31-32)

And in the verse:

"And my brother Aaron is more eloquent than me in speech, so send him with me as a helper to confirm me. Indeed, I fear that they will deny me." (al-Qasas/28: 34)

As a favor and mercy from Allah to Moses, Allah granted Moses' request, as mentioned in the verse:

He (Allah) said, "You have been granted your request, O Moses!" (Taha/20: 36)

Regarding the request of Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) for Prophet Aaron, some of the Salaf scholars (predecessors), including Ibn Jarir al-Tabari, said, "There is no one who can give intercession to another greater than the intercession given to Aaron through the mediation of Prophet Moses." According to a narration from Ibn Abbas, Aaron was about 4 years older than Moses at that time.
text.54:
In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to relate the story of Ismail, the ancestor of the Arabs, whom Allah elevated to be a prophet and messenger, so that he could be an example for them in his qualities, loyalty, honesty, steadfastness, and patience in carrying out the commands of his Lord, and his obedience and submission. One of the most prominent qualities was fulfilling promises. Fulfilling promises is a characteristic possessed by every messenger and prophet, but this quality was so prominent in Ismail that Allah made it a special distinction for him.

Among the promises he fulfilled, even though the promise endangered his life, was his willingness to be slaughtered as a sacrifice to carry out Allah's command to his father Ibrahim, which he received through *ar-ruyah ash-shadiqah* (a true dream) that is equivalent to revelation. When Ibrahim discussed with Ismail about Allah's command to slaughter him, Ismail firmly stated that he was willing to be slaughtered for the sake of obeying Allah's command, and that he would be steadfast and patient in facing death, no matter how painful and agonizing it might be. This is mentioned in the verse:

"Then, when he reached (the age of) working with him, he said, "O my son, indeed I have seen in a dream that I [must] sacrifice you, so see what you think." He said, "O my father, do as you are commanded. You will find me, if Allah wills, of the steadfast." (ash-Shaffat/37: 102)

That was Ismail's promise to his father Ibrahim. Ismail truly fulfilled that promise, and he surrendered himself to his father, who was ready with a sharp knife to slaughter him. Ibrahim, even with great compassion and pity, laid Ismail down to facilitate the slaughter, and the knife was aimed at his neck. At that moment, Allah called out to Ibrahim and replaced Ismail with a large, fat ram. This is narrated by Allah in His words:

"And when they had both submitted and he put him down upon his forehead, We called to him, "O Abraham, You have fulfilled the vision." Indeed, We thus reward the doers of good. Indeed, this was a clear trial. And We ransomed him with a great sacrifice." (ash-Shaffat/37: 103-107)

In addition to that prominent quality, Ismail was appointed by Allah as a prophet and messenger to the Jurhum tribe who settled in Mecca with his mother. As a messenger, Ismail was tasked by Allah to convey the message, namely the message that his father, the Prophet Ibrahim, had conveyed to the Jurhum tribe. Indeed, before the Prophet Muhammad was sent as a messenger, there were people among the Arabs who adhered to the concept of *tawhid* (monotheism), and it is highly likely that the concept of *tawhid* they adhered to was the concept brought and conveyed by Ismail to his people.
text.55:
In this verse, Allah explains that Ismail always instructed his family to consistently perform prayer (salat) and pay zakat, because prayer and zakat had been prescribed since the time of Prophet Ibrahim. The message conveyed by Prophet Ismail was the same message brought by his father, Ibrahim. Although only his family is mentioned here, the command encompasses his entire people, because a messenger is not sent solely for his family but is sent for all of his people. Prophet Muhammad himself was initially only commanded to convey the teachings of Islam to his family and then later commanded to invite all of mankind to follow the teachings he brought. This is found in Allah's words:

"And warn, [O Muhammad], your closest relatives," (ash-Shu'ara'/26: 214)

And His words:

"And enjoin prayer upon your family [and people] and be patient therein." (Taha/20: 132)

Then, Allah explains that Ismail was a person who was pleasing to Allah because he never neglected to obey the commands of his Lord, and always carried out his duties in the best possible way.
text.56:
In these two verses, Prophet Muhammad is commanded to also explain a small piece of news about Prophet Idris. According to some narrations, Prophet Idris is the ancestor of Prophet Noah (peace be upon him). According to the most famous narration, he is the paternal ancestor of Prophet Noah. He was the first person to investigate the science of stars and arithmetic, as one of the miracles given to him by Allah. He was the first messenger sent by Allah after Adam (peace be upon him), and a book consisting of thirty pages was revealed to him. He is also considered the first person to create scales and measures, pens for writing, sewn clothes as a replacement for animal skin clothing, and weapons for war. Allah explains in this verse the high position of Prophet Idris because he was a believer who affirmed the power and oneness of Allah, and He raised him to be a prophet and elevated his rank to the highest level, both in this world and in the hereafter. As for in this world, it is through the acceptance of the message he brought by his people and the fragrance of his name among mankind. This is the same as Allah's grace to Prophet Muhammad as mentioned in Allah's word:

"And raised high for you your repute." (ash-Sharh/94: 4)

In the hereafter, he will be placed in Paradise in the highest and most noble place, the place of the prophets and the *shiddiqin* as mentioned in the verse:

And whoever obeys Allah and the Messenger (Muhammad) - those will be with the ones upon whom Allah has bestowed favor - of the prophets, the *shiddiqin*, the martyrs, and the righteous. And excellent are those as companions. (an-Nisa'/4: 69).

text.58:
In this verse, Allah explains that the prophets and messengers whose names have been mentioned in the previous verses are those who have been granted grace and blessings by Allah, elevating their status and making their names fragrant among mankind. In general, all prophets and messengers received such grace, from Prophet Adam, the first father, to Prophet Noah, the second father, to Prophet Ibrahim and his descendants, including Isaac, Jacob, Ishmael, Moses, Aaron, Zechariah, Jesus, and all His chosen ones. All of them possessed a quality rarely found in others: when the verses of Allah were recited to them, they immediately fell down (prostrated) to prostrate and weep, humbling themselves in remembrance of Allah's greatness. They were people full of piety, with very sharp hearing and feelings; when they heard the name of Allah, their hearts trembled, and when His verses were recited, they had no words to express what they felt in their hearts, so tears streamed down their cheeks and they fell prostrate before Allah, the Most Great, the Most Powerful, the Most Compassionate, and the Most Merciful. Such were the qualities possessed by the prophets and messengers, and it is fitting that Allah bestowed upon them great grace and blessings. This is also mentioned in Allah's word:

"The believers are only those who, when Allah is mentioned, their hearts tremble; and when His verses are recited to them, it increases them in faith; and upon their Lord they rely." (al-Anfal/8: 2)

The Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

"Read the Qur'an and weep, and if you cannot weep, then strive to weep." (Narrated by Ibn Majah)
text.59:
In this verse, Allah explains that many among the people who came later, after the death of the prophets and messengers mentioned in the previous verses, deviated from the straight path, abandoning the teachings brought by the previous messengers, so that they no longer performed *salat* and always indulged in their desires, openly violating Allah's prohibitions such as drinking alcohol, gambling, committing adultery, and giving false testimony. These people are threatened by Allah with a severe threat; they will be afflicted with misfortune and loss both in this world and in the hereafter. In connection with this verse, Abu Sa'id al-Khudri narrated that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

"There will come a generation after sixty years, they will neglect *salat* and indulge in their desires, so these people will meet with misfortune and loss. Then another generation will come, they will read the Qur'an but only in their throats (mouths) (not entering the heart) and everyone will read the Qur'an, the believer, the hypocrite, and the wicked and immoral (it is no longer possible to distinguish between a true believer and one who pretends to believe)." (Narrated by Ahmad, Ibn Hibban, and al-Hakim)

Then the Messenger of Allah recited this verse (as mentioned above).

'Uqbah bin 'Amir also narrated that he heard the Messenger of Allah say:

"A part of my *ummah* will be destroyed, namely "Ahlul Kitab" and "Ahlullaban." I asked, "Who are "Ahlul Kitab," O Messenger of Allah?" He replied, "They are those who study the Qur'an to argue with the believers." "Then who are "Ahlullaban"?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "They are those who indulge in their desires and abandon *salat*." (Narrated by Ahmad and al-Hakim from 'Uqbah bin 'Amir al-Juhhani)

Such is the fate of those who neglect *salat* and indulge in their desires and waste it; they will surely suffer loss, even though what they suffer cannot be seen with the eyes, and they will surely receive a fitting reward in the hereafter. Here it is clear that *salat*, which has been a *sharia* since Prophet Ibrahim, is very important and should not be wasted, let alone abandoned. It is narrated that Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

"*Salat* is the pillar of religion. Whoever establishes it has established the religion, and whoever abandons it has destroyed the religion." (Narrated by al-Baihaqi from Umar r.a.)
text.60: In this verse, Allah explains that those people mentioned in verse 59, if they repent and return to performing righteous deeds, Allah will forgive their sins and admit them into Paradise, and they will not be wronged in the slightest. Such is the decree of Allah, the Most Just, the Most Generous, and the Most Merciful. Even if someone has been deeply immersed in the abyss of disobedience, deceived and deluded by the fleeting pleasures of this world, if they become aware and return to the right path and repent to Allah with a sincere repentance, Allah will accept their repentance with the conditions and stipulations explained in other verses.
text.61: This verse explains that the Paradise promised by Allah, which will be the abode for those who repent and are pious, is the Garden of 'Adn. Although the promised Paradise cannot be seen by humans in this world, because it is still unseen (ghaib), and when humans will definitely enter it cannot be known for certain because all of that is only known by Allah. But for those who believe and are certain about the occurrence of the Day of Resurrection and the Reckoning (hisab), there is no doubt whatsoever because it is the promise of Allah, the Most Perfect, the Most Just, and the Most Wise. Surely that promise will be fulfilled by Him and will be carried out by Him.
text.62:
Allah also explains that in Paradise, there will be no disputes, no useless words will be heard as happens in the world where humans, for their own interests or for the interests of their families and groups, are always in conflict, arguing, accusing each other endlessly, causing them to lose peace and prosperity. They are even filled with anxiety and worry. It is different in Paradise because humans have entered another world, all desires can be achieved and enjoyed, there is no more hostility or competition between them to achieve something, so only greetings of peace (selamat sejahtera) are heard, whether the greetings come from angels or from each other. Everyone feels safe and secure because every morning and evening they are given sustenance by their Lord, sustenance whose pleasure and delicious taste cannot be imagined in anyone's mind. Allah describes the blessings prepared for the inhabitants of Paradise, as mentioned in a Hadith Qudsi:

"I have prepared for My righteous servants what no eye has seen, what no ear has heard, and what no human heart has ever conceived." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)
text.63:
Such is the atmosphere within Paradise: safe and peaceful, an atmosphere of happiness and prosperity. Its inhabitants feel relieved and satisfied with the blessings and favors bestowed upon them by their Lord, and Allah is pleased with them because they were always obedient and devoted to Him in the world, patient in facing His trials, as mentioned in His word:

Allah says, "This is the Day when the truthful will benefit from their truthfulness. For them are gardens [in Paradise] beneath which rivers flow, wherein they will abide forever. Allah is pleased with them, and they are pleased with Him. That is the great attainment." (al-Ma'idah/5: 119)

Such is the state and nature of Paradise that He will bequeath to His servants who truly believe and are always mindful of Him, as mentioned in His word:

Close friends, that Day, will be enemies to each other, except for the righteous. "[To them will be said], 'O My servants, no fear will there be concerning you this Day, nor will you grieve. [You are] those who believed in Our verses and were Muslims [submitting to Allah]. Enter Paradise, you and your kinds, delighted.' Circulated among them will be plates and vessels of gold. And therein is whatever souls desire and [what] delights the eyes, and you will abide therein eternally. And that is Paradise which you are made to inherit for what you used to do. Therein for you is much fruit from which you will eat." (az-Zukhruf/43: 63-73)
text.64: In this verse, Gabriel affirms to the Prophet Muhammad that the angels will not be able to descend with revelation to the messengers except when they have received an order from Allah in accordance with His will and wisdom, and in accordance with the interests of His servants, whether regarding worldly or hereafterly matters. He is the One who possesses all that is before us and behind us and that which is between them; He is the One who manages and regulates it. Therefore, He is also the One who knows best what is good and what is not good for His creation. He is the One who determines when the angels will descend to His Messenger to bring revelation, and for how long He allows the angels not to descend to them, in accordance with His knowledge and wisdom. So, if the angels are late in sending down revelation to the Messenger, it is not because Allah has abandoned the Messenger, is angry, or has forgotten him. It is impossible for Allah to be negligent and forgetful.
text.65: How could God be negligent and forgetful when He is the One who owns, manages, and controls everything in the heavens and the earth and everything in between? Allah, the All-Powerful and All-Wise, would never be negligent or forgetful in managing and arranging all of His creation. Therefore, the Messenger should not think that Allah has been angry with him due to the delay in revelation. All of that occurs according to His will and wisdom. The Messenger is commanded to wait patiently and continue to worship Him, regardless of whatever nonsense the polytheists utter. Indeed, Allah is the One and Only God; nothing can be compared to Him. Therefore, it is to Him that mankind must surrender, obey, and dutifully carry out His commands.
text.66:
Al-Wahidi narrated that this verse was revealed concerning Ubay bin Khalaf. He took a piece of bone that was almost crumbled and crushed it with his hands like flour, then scattered it into the strong wind, so the bone scattered. Then he said, "Some people say that we will be resurrected after we die and after we become like this bone." Is it possible that if I have died, I will be resurrected and brought back to life? Such questions are also found in other verses:

And they say, "When we have died and become dust and bones, will we truly be resurrected?" (al-Waqi'ah/56: 47)

And His saying:

And they say, "When we are bones and fragments, will we truly be resurrected as a new creation?" (al-Isra'/17: 49)

Such are the questions raised by those who are shallow in thought and unwilling to think deeply about the power of Allah, because the eyes of their hearts have been covered by misguidance and the pleasures of worldly life, so that the light of truth is no longer visible to them. Therefore, Allah rejects their questions. Do people with such thoughts not know that Allah created them from nothing? Is there anyone who can create something from nothing, and can also create it from something that exists, even if it is bones or fragments? This is a strange thought that will not arise except from people whose hearts have been shrouded in denial and are unwilling to think about the matter carefully and deeply. In another verse, Allah says:

And it is He who begins the creation; then He will repeat it, and that is easier for Him. To Him belongs the highest attribute in the heavens and earth. And He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise. (ar-Rum/30: 27)

And His saying:

And he presents for Us an example and forgets his [own] creation. He says, "Who will give life to bones while they are disintegrated?" Say, "He will give them life who produced them the first time; and He is, of all creation, Knowing." (Yasin/36: 78-79)

In a Qudsi hadith, Allah says:

"The son of Adam has denied Me, and he has no right to deny Me. The son of Adam has harmed Me, and he has no right to harm Me. As for his denial of Me, it is his saying that I will not resurrect him as I created him the first time. Creating him the first time is not easier for Me than creating him again (meaning it is equally easy). As for his harming Me, it is his saying: Indeed, I have a son, while I am the One God, upon Whom all things depend, who neither begets nor is born, and there is none comparable to Me." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah)

text.68:
Therefore, Allah threatens such people by swearing that He will gather them in the gathering place (padang mahsyar) together with the devils they considered their leaders. They will see and experience how terrible and great the atmosphere will be at that time, so that no one will think of anything except their own safety, as stated in Allah's words:

"On the Day a man will flee from his brother, and from his mother and his father, and from his wife and his children. For every man, that Day, will be a matter adequate for him." ('Abasa/80: 34-37)

In that very critical and dangerous atmosphere, they will be driven to hell in a kneeling and humiliated state, unable to stand because of the very bitter experience and indescribable suffering.
text.69:
Therefore, Allah threatens such people by swearing that He will gather them in the gathering place (padang mahsyar) together with the devils they considered their leaders. They will see and experience how terrible and great the atmosphere will be at that time, so that no one thinks of anything except their own safety, as mentioned in Allah's words:

"On the Day a man will flee from his brother, and his mother and his father, and his wife and his children, for every person among them that Day will have a matter occupying him." ('Abasa/80: 34-37)

In that very critical and dangerous atmosphere, they are driven to hell in a kneeling and humiliated state, unable to stand because of the very bitter experience and indescribable suffering.
text.70:
The disbelievers are gathered in groups according to their level of wickedness, then Allah separates the most denying, arrogant, and rebellious, and those who most misled people on earth from each group to be thrown into hell first. For Allah, the All-Knowing, Whose Knowledge is Vast, it is not difficult to determine such people because all their deeds in the world have been recorded in each person's book, as mentioned in His word:

"On that Day you will be exhibited [before Allah], not concealed will be any secret of yours." (al-haqqah/69: 18)

They will be shackled, thrown into hell, and even in hell they will be chained, as mentioned in His word:

"(Allah will say), "Seize him and shackle him, Then into Hellfire drive him. Then into a chain whose length is seventy cubits insert him." (al-haqqah/69: 30-32)

After that, it will be the turn of the others to be thrown into hell according to their level of disbelief and wickedness.
text.71:
Then Allah directed His word to all of mankind and explained that everyone will be brought to the place where Hell is located. They will be brought near to that Hell and stand around it. This has already become His decree that cannot be changed and must be fulfilled.

In a hadith from Muslim narrated by Abu Sa'id al-Khudriy, it is explained ("...then a bridge will be erected over Hell, and intercession will be permitted. They will say, 'O Allah, save us, save us.' The Messenger of Allah was asked, 'What is the bridge?' The Messenger of Allah replied, 'A slippery place to step, with hooks and barbs, and thorns (like) those in Najd, which have small thorns called as-Sa'dan. There are believers who will pass in the blink of an eye, like lightning, the wind, a flying bird, a racing horse, and like a rider. Some will be saved, caught and released, and some will be thrown into Hell Jahannam.")
text.72:
This verse affirms that Allah at that time released the righteous from the torment of hell and allowed the disbelievers to fall into it in a kneeling state. Allah explains that those released from the torment of hell are the righteous, not just those who believe, because those who believe are not necessarily among the righteous, as many believers violate Allah's commands and commit His prohibitions. If their sins outweigh their good deeds, then they will be punished first in hell according to the sins they committed, and then they will be brought out of hell after receiving punishment commensurate with their sins, and then admitted to Paradise. As for those whose good deeds outweigh their sins, they will be admitted to Paradise after their sins have been forgiven by Allah with His mercy and compassion. This is mentioned in Allah's words:

"Then as for him whose scales are heavy [with good deeds], He will be in a pleasant life. But as for him whose scales are light, His refuge will be an abyss. And what will make you know what that is? [It is] a burning fire." (al-Qari'ah/101: 6-11)
text.73:
In this verse, Allah explains the attitude of the disbelievers when the verses of the Qur'an, whose truth is evident and undeniable, are recited to them. The words that come out of their mouths to oppose the truth of those verses are mockery and ridicule. They say to the believers, "Who among us has the most pleasant life, the most peaceful mind, the best house, the highest position, and the largest number?" How could we, who are far higher and more noble than all of you, be in falsehood and following a misguided path? This is impossible. Therefore, we consider you to be the ones in error because your group is weak, miserable, and small in number. You can only gather in secret to discuss your affairs in isolated and secluded places like Darul Arqam and so on. It is impossible that the religion you follow is the true religion and it is impossible that the verses of the Qur'an are good and beneficial. Because if that were the case, we would be the first to believe and trust in it." That is the only reason and explanation that the disbelievers can put forward to the believers, and their explanation like this is also found in another verse:

And those who disbelieve say of those who believe, "If the Qur'an had been a good thing, they would not have preceded us to it." But when they are not guided by it, they will say, "This is an ancient falsehood." (al-Ahqaf/46: 11)
text.74: Allah refutes the mockery of the disbelievers by explaining that in the past, He destroyed many peoples because of their disobedience, such as the people of 'Ad and Thamud, even though they were richer and more luxurious than the disbelievers of Mecca, and their lands were fertile and had beautiful scenery. So, the wealth, luxury of the inhabitants, and beauty of a land are not criteria for judging a people to be on the right side and favored by Allah. The measure is faith in Allah and obedience and compliance in carrying out His commands and abandoning His prohibitions. If wealth and luxury were truly the measure, then they would not have been destroyed by Allah. In reality, this verse is a threat from Allah to the polytheists of Mecca; if they do not become aware and repent and continue to rebel, it is not impossible that they will also be destroyed like previous nations.
text.75:
In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad to respond to the mockery and ridicule of the polytheists who boasted of their wealth by saying that those who were astray from his people would not be destroyed by Allah at this time, because of His mercy and compassion and because the Prophet Muhammad and the believers were among them. This is mentioned in His word:

"But Allah would not punish them while you, [O Muhammad], are among them, and Allah would not punish them while they seek forgiveness." (al-Anfal/8: 33)

Allah will leave them and postpone and give them the opportunity to wallow in disbelief and disobedience until the time comes when they will see for themselves Allah's punishment in this world with the total defeat they experience (such as the Battle of Badr and the expulsion of the polytheists of Mecca), and in the Hereafter they will see who is truly more noble, receives Allah's mercy and grace, and who will receive a humiliating punishment so that their position is so vile and so low.
text.76: As solace for the Muslims who were being insulted and mocked, because indeed they were powerless to answer the challenges of the polytheists who boasted of their wealth, Allah promises to give them additional guidance besides the guidance they had already received. With that guidance, they will be more pious and happier. Let the disbelievers boast of their wealth and position and always be in arrogance and pride. Let them continue in error and disobedience. At some point, Allah will inflict His severe punishment upon them. At that time, they will realize that they have made a great mistake and regret it greatly, but that regret will not help them in the slightest, because it will be like spilled milk, regret beforehand is profitable, regret afterward is useless. In facing the arrogance of the polytheists, the Muslims should be patient and steadfast, always practicing Allah's guidance, obedient and compliant to His commands. Thus, their hearts will be open, their minds will be calm, and their good deeds will increase. They will always be under the protection of His mercy and love. Allah will provide them with multiplied rewards.
text.77: In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad (saw) to observe how arrogant and haughty the disbelievers are, daring to say that in the Hereafter they will be granted abundant wealth and children. Although this statement seems to indicate that they believe in the Day of Resurrection, in reality, they do not believe in the Day of Resurrection at all. Such a statement is only a mockery and ridicule of the believers' faith, implying that if Khabbab bin Arat truly believed in the Day of Resurrection, then his debt should be paid on the Day of Resurrection. Now he refuses to pay it because Khabbab believes in Muhammad. This mockery is further compounded by saying that he will be rich and have many children in the Hereafter. How audacious he is to fabricate something he does not know at all, while he himself denies the unseen (ghaib).
text.78: Therefore, in this verse, Allah rebukes him by saying, "Does he know the unseen, or has he taken a covenant with Allah that He will give him abundant sustenance and children?" Both possibilities are very remote, because no one can know the unseen, especially that which relates to the Hereafter. And it is impossible for him to have taken a covenant with God that he will be given abundant sustenance in the Hereafter, while he himself denies that Day and associates partners with Allah in the form of idols. The place for such a person is Hell, and the punishment that will be inflicted upon him will certainly be severe.
text.79:
In this verse, Allah threatens them with a severe threat because of their audacity in attributing something to Allah without knowledge and without a rationally justifiable basis. Allah will take all their wealth as a fitting recompense for their denial and disobedience and punish them with an unending torment. Allah will take all their wealth and children that they leave behind when they die, so that in the Hereafter they will come before Allah alone, with no one to defend or help them. Indeed, on that day nothing can help a person except their faith and good deeds, in accordance with Allah's word:

"(It is) the Day when wealth or children will be of no avail, except for whoever brings to Allah a sound heart." (ash-Shu'ara/26: 88-89)

"And they will be presented before your Lord in rows, (and He will say), "You have certainly come to Us just as We created you the first time. But you claimed that We would never make for you an appointment." (al-Kahf/18: 48)
text.80:
In this verse, Allah threatens them with a severe threat because of their audacity in attributing something to Allah without knowledge and without a rational basis that can be accounted for. Allah will take all their wealth as a fitting recompense for their denial and disobedience and punish them with an unending torment. Allah will take all their wealth and children that they leave behind when they die, so that in the Hereafter they will come before Allah alone, with no one to defend or help them. Indeed, on that day nothing can help a person except their faith and good deeds, in accordance with Allah's word:

"(It is) the Day when wealth or children will be of no avail, except for those who come to Allah with a sound heart." (ash-Shu'ara/26: 88-89)

And they will be brought before your Lord in rows. (Allah will say), "You have certainly come to Us just as We created you the first time. But you claimed that We would never make for you an appointment." (al-Kahf/18: 48)
text.81: In this verse, Allah explains to the Prophet Muhammad saw that the intention and purpose of the polytheists in worshipping idols and other objects of worship is so that these idols and objects of worship can help them, both in this world and in the Hereafter. They offer various kinds of goods and money to these idols with the hope that the idols can grant their requests, be given blessings and be blessed in life, business and work, and so that they remain happy, noble and honorable. Among them, it is as if the idol is the most powerful, entitled to bestow grace and blessings, entitled to inflict torment and misery. In the Hereafter (according to their understanding), these idols will be able to intercede for them and will help them when they face difficulties or experience suffering.
text.82:
This verse refutes that erroneous understanding, especially regarding the idols' ability to provide assistance in the afterlife. Those idols and objects of worship will absolutely not be able to help them; in fact, they will deny before Allah that they were worshipped by those polytheists, as mentioned in Allah's words:

"And when those who associated partners with Allah see their 'partners,' they will say, "Our Lord, these are our partners whom we used to invoke besides You." But the 'partners' will throw back at them the statement, "Indeed, you are liars." (an-Nahl/16: 86)

And His words:

"[That will be] when those who were followed disassociate themselves from those who followed [them], and they [all] see the punishment, and severed are the ties among them. And those who followed will say, "If only we had another chance [at returning to the world] so we could disassociate ourselves from them as they have disassociated themselves from us." Thus will Allah show them their deeds as regrets upon them. And they will never emerge from the Fire." (al-Baqarah/2: 166-167)
text.83: In this verse, Allah warns Prophet Muhammad that He has released Satan and given him the opportunity to deceive, persuade, and mislead people who are affected by Satan's temptations, including the disbelievers of Mecca. As a result, they will remain in error and will not return to the right path, no matter how much Muhammad invites and calls them. Allah explains this as a solace to Prophet Muhammad's heart, which was grieving because he had sincerely and wholeheartedly given guidance and warnings to them, but they still denied and refused to believe.
text.84:
In this verse, Allah forbids the Prophet Muhammad from feeling sad and angry towards the disbelievers and asks that the punishment for them be hastened because the time to inflict the punishment is near, only a matter of counting the days. In this world, they will receive retribution with their defeat in the Battle of Badr, and in the Hereafter, even though it seems far away in our minds, for Allah that day is near. Because one day in the Hereafter in Allah's reckoning is not 24 hours as in our calculation, perhaps a thousand years or perhaps more, as mentioned in His word:

And they urge you to hasten the punishment. And Allah will never fail in His promise. And indeed, a day with your Lord is like a thousand years of which you count. (al-hajj/22: 47)
text.85: On that Day, Allah will gather the righteous to appear before His presence as an honored delegation because of their faith and deeds in the world. They will be brought on fine and beautiful vehicles as respected guests. Ali bin Abi Talib said that this delegation is not an ordinary group walking or being herded, but they are brought on vehicles whose beauty has never been seen by humans, upon which are seats of gold and reins inlaid with emerald jewels, until they reach the gates of Paradise.
text.86: Conversely, the rebellious who remain disbelieving and infidel are driven to hell. On the journey to hell, they suffer various indescribable torments such as thirst and hunger due to the heat of the Mahsyar plain. They are driven like lowly, powerless animals, not to a shady place or a clear spring to quench their thirst, but to a blazing hell.
text.87:
The disbelievers will not obtain intercession from anyone to help them or alleviate the suffering they experience. For those who are entitled to receive intercession on that day are only those whom Allah has promised will receive intercession, namely the believers who, during their lives in the world, have prepared themselves to receive intercession through their good deeds and their struggle to uphold the word of Allah. Intercession on that day is only possessed by the prophets, scholars, and martyrs, according to their respective deeds and services. Among the acts of worship that entitle a person to obtain intercession is maintaining the five daily prayers in the best possible way.

The Messenger of Allah said, "Whoever comes on the Day of Judgment bringing his five daily prayers perfectly, meaning he perfects his ablution, preserves its time, performs its bowing and prostration, and never abandons it even once, then Allah promises not to punish him. But the person who has ever abandoned his prayer will not obtain that promise from Allah. It is up to the Lord whether He will grant him mercy or inflict punishment upon him." (Narrated by ath-Thabrani in the book "al-Ausath" from Abu Hurairah)
text.88:
In this verse, Allah affirms that those who say that Allah has a child, whether they are from the polytheists of Mecca, the Jews, the Christians, or followers of other religions, are misguided because they have uttered a very displeasing statement and have fabricated a great falsehood against Allah. This statement is very reprehensible, unacceptable to reason, and highly contradictory to the attributes of Allah, the One, the Creator, the Almighty, and the All-Powerful. Allah is very angry with them because their impudence degrades the Most High, as if Allah is equated with humans and His other creatures who need offspring to continue their existence in the future and who will help and assist them when they have become weak and helpless. Whereas He is the Ever-Living, eternally self-sufficient, not needing help or assistance from anyone other than Him, as mentioned in His word:

"Allah - there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of [all] existence." (Ali 'Imran/3: 2)

Allah severely rebukes them and says that with such statements, they have said something very reprehensible, a statement that should not come out of the mouths of His creatures whom He Himself created, creatures whom He has bestowed with reason and intellect so that they can distinguish between what is right and what is wrong.
