text.90: If the earth, the heavens, and the mountains could hear and understand the words of the disbelievers, even though they were not given intellect and thought by Allah, then the heavens, the earth, and the great mountains would be violently shaken with shock and perhaps would be utterly destroyed, because they could not accept words that are so heavy in responsibility, and so insulting and degrading to the dignity of their Creator. Fortunately, the earth, the heavens, and the mountains cannot hear, let alone understand, the very erroneous words of the disbelievers.
text.91: If the earth, the heavens, and the mountains could hear and understand the words of the disbelievers, even though Allah did not grant them reason and intellect, then the heavens, the earth, and those great mountains would be violently shaken with shock and perhaps would be utterly destroyed, because they could not bear the words that carry such a heavy responsibility, and so greatly insult and degrade the dignity of their Creator. Fortunately, the earth, the heavens, and the mountains cannot hear, let alone understand, the very erroneous words of the disbelievers.
text.92: In this verse, Allah refutes with His saying, "It is not befitting for the Most Merciful to take a son." This is the answer of Allah, the Most Compassionate and Merciful, to the words of His servants that greatly angered Him. He did not rebuke and punish them directly, but answered them with words that should be deeply considered so that they return to the truth and sanctify their Lord from all attributes that contradict His oneness and majesty.
text.93: In this verse, Allah also affirms that everything in the heavens and on earth, whether angels, jinn, or humans, will all come before Allah's (their Lord's) presence on the Day of Judgment as servants, obedient and submissive to all the decrees and punishments that He decides for each of His creatures. No one will be able to deny His judgment at that time because the judgment is a just judgment. Some will be entitled to receive torment and punishment according to the disobedience and evil they committed, while others will be entitled to receive rewards and blessings according to the piety and good deeds they strived for.
text.94: Then Allah explains that all their deeds and piety have been recorded in a very meticulous and detailed book, and no one is omitted from that record. All their actions, both small and large, all their words, both open and hidden, have been written and calculated with the utmost precision, and they are all waiting for the reward they will receive.
text.95:
On the Day of Judgment, the disbelievers will come before Allah to receive the reckoning and judgment regarding their deeds, each one alone, not accompanied by even their closest relatives, such as their children or spouses.

Such is the decree that Allah has established for every servant on that day. No one can escape His judgment. Everyone will surely face that momentous and terrifying event with feelings of hope and anxiety, wondering whether they will be among the wretched who will be driven to Hell in a state of humiliation, or among the fortunate who will be welcomed into Paradise with honor and dignity.
text.96:
This verse explains that Allah will instill a sense of compassion in the hearts of His believing servants, those who are pious and consistently perform righteous deeds. This means that anyone who truly believes and always does good deeds will surely have a good place in the heart of every Muslim. Even if the believer never tries to attract the hearts of others, people will surely be drawn to him, because the instillation of sympathy and affection for the believer is not just in the form of sweet words and good speech, but because Allah Himself instills that affection into the hearts of His servants. In a hadith narrated by Abu Hurairah, the Messenger of Allah said:

Indeed, when Allah loves one of His servants, He calls the angel Jibril and says to him, "Indeed, I love so-and-so, so you should love him too." Then it is proclaimed in the heavens, and then affection for him descends upon the earth. (Riwayat al-Bukhari, Muslim dan at-Tirmidzi)

Regarding this verse, Ibn Mardawaih and ad-Dailami narrated from al-Bara' who said that the Messenger of Allah (saw) said to Ali Karramallahu wajhah:

Say, "O Allah, give me Your promise (so that I may be saved in the Hereafter) and instill in the hearts of the believers love for me." Then this verse was revealed. (Riwayat Ibnu Mardawaih dan ad-Dailami)

Indeed, if we observe human life in society, the truth of this verse will be proven. Anyone who truly believes, is truly sincere in his good deeds, truly works for the benefit of his community without expecting money, rank, or position, and solely seeks divine pleasure, will surely be loved by his community even if he himself does not strive in that direction. If there is someone who hates or is angry with him, then surely the one who is angry is someone whose intentions are not good, does not have noble character, and is tempted by the deception of Satan and Iblis.
text.97:
Allah explains that the Qur'an was revealed in Arabic, the language used by the Prophet Muhammad and his people, so that it would be easy for the Prophet to convey its contents and meaning, and easy for his people to understand, because they were the first to whom the call of Islam was delivered, and then to all of humanity from various tribes and languages. The Qur'an, which contains warnings and good news, commands and prohibitions, aims to give guidance to mankind to be pious to Allah, that is, to believe in Him without associating anything with Him, and to obey His commands, stop His prohibitions, and always seek His pleasure. Those who have such qualities will be granted happiness in this world and in the hereafter.

As for those who deny Him and deny His Messenger, they will receive a fitting reward for their denial and disobedience, both in this world and in the hereafter. The denial of past nations was rewarded in this world by destroying and annihilating them with various kinds of punishments, some in the form of violent earthquakes, hurricanes, loud thunderous sounds, and so on, as was inflicted upon the people of 'Ad, Thamud, and the people of Prophet Noah. As for the people of Muhammad, the punishment in this world is not in the form of destruction and annihilation, but by sending down trials and disasters, with the hope that they will realize and repent and return to the truth. The recompense in the hereafter is by bestowing His grace upon the pious believers by admitting them into *Jannatun Na'im*, a paradise full of blessings and pleasures, and receiving His love and pleasure.

For those who deny and disbelieve, a painful punishment is prepared, namely hell. As proof of the truth of His threat, Allah explains that many disobedient nations of the past have been destroyed, and the traces of their remains can still be seen and witnessed until now, and some have no traces at all. But what is clear is that those nations have been destroyed and annihilated, with no one left until today, only their stories that are narrated by people from generation to generation. The news about them is told in the Qur'an clearly, so we must believe it because the source is the revelation of Allah.
